appellants: Vinod Aggarwal trading as Vaneet Sales Corporation
key_issues: Trademark rectification and cancellation of the impugned trademark 'BAL BIHAR SUPER'
Registration of a deceptively similar trademark 'LAL BAHAR CHHAAP' by a third party
Opposition to the registration of a similar trademark and its subsequent abandonment
Passing off and infringement of the petitioner's trademark 'LAL BIHARI CHAAP'
Validity and subsistence of the petitioner's trademark registrations in Class 34
Copyright ownership of the artistic work in the 'LAL BIHARI CHAAP' labels
Misuse of a similar trademark, packaging, and trade dress by a third party
Cancellation/removal of the impugned trademark from the Register of Trade Marks
Procedure for re-numbering a civil original trademark rectification petition
Enforcement of intellectual property rights and protection against unfair trade practices
metadata.decision_summary:
**Background:**
The case involves a trademark rectification petition filed by Vinod Aggarwal Trading as Vaneet Sales Corporation (the petitioner) against Meera Devi and another (the respondents). The petitioner is engaged in the business of manufacturing and trading tobacco products and has registered the trademark 'LAL BIHARI CHAAP' in Class 34. The petitioner claims to have been using this trademark since 1990 and has also obtained copyright for the artistic work in the 'LAL BIHARI CHAAP' labels.

**Legal Issues:**
The legal issue in this case revolves around the registration of the trademark 'BAL BIHARI SUPER' (word per se) by the respondent, Meera Devi, under application no. 4256368 in Class 34. The petitioner alleges that this trademark is deceptively similar to their registered trademark 'LAL BIHARI CHAAP' and is likely to cause confusion among consumers.

**Arguments:**
The petitioner argues that they have been using the 'LAL BIHARI CHAAP' trademark for over three decades and have established a significant reputation in the market. They claim that the respondent's attempt to register the 'BAL BIHARI SUPER' trademark is an attempt to ride on their reputation and cause confusion among consumers. The petitioner also points out that the respondent's husband, Mr. Raghupati Maurya, had previously applied for a similar trademark 'LAL BAHAR CHHAAP', which was opposed by the petitioner and ultimately abandoned.

**Court Findings:**
The court notes that the petitioner has established a significant reputation in the market with their 'LAL BIHARI CHAAP' trademark and has obtained copyright for the artistic work in the labels. The court also observes that the respondent's application for the 'BAL BIHARI SUPER' trademark was filed on a proposed to be used basis, which raises suspicions about the respondent's intentions.

**Decision:**
The court directs the Registry to re-number the present petition as a civil original trademark rectification petition. The court also notes that the petition is at a preliminary stage and that the respondents have not filed any response to the petition. The court orders the respondents to file their response to the petition within a specified timeframe.

**Conclusion:**
In conclusion, the case involves a trademark rectification petition filed by the petitioner against the respondent's registration of the 'BAL BIHARI SUPER' trademark. The petitioner argues that this trademark is deceptively similar to their registered trademark 'LAL BIHARI CHAAP' and is likely to cause confusion among consumers. The court has directed the Registry to re-number the petition and has ordered the respondents to file their response to the petition. The outcome of the case will depend on the response filed by the respondents and the court's subsequent findings.

tree_structure.summary:
According to the PDF document "Vinod Agarwal vs Meera Devi.pdf", a legal proceeding was held in the High Court of Delhi at New Delhi, dated March 10, 2023. The case number is C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 41/2022, and the decision was made by Amit Bansal, J. The appellant, Vinod Aggarwal, trading as Vaneet Sales Corporation, was represented by Ms. Purva Chugh and Ms. Sonia Sharma, Advocates.

The respondent, Meera Devi, had a trademark registration under application no. 4256368 in Class 34, which the appellant contested. The court found that the adoption of the trademark "BAL BIIHARI SUPER" by the respondent was dishonest, as her husband had acknowledged the petitioner's right to the trademark/label "LAL BIHARI CHAAP" and undertaken not to use similar marks.

The court ruled in favor of the appellant, stating that the respondent's registration could not have been granted under Section 11 of the Trade Marks Act, 1999. The petitioner was found to be the prior adopter and continuous user of the trademark since February 12, 1990. The court ordered the removal of the trademark registered under application no. 4256368 in the name of the respondent from the Register of Trade Marks, citing Section 57 of the Act. The pending application was also disposed of, and the Registry was directed to supply a copy of the order to the Trademark Registry for compliance (Source: Vinod Agarwal vs Meera Devi.pdf, 2023/DHC/001820).

The petitioner is the prior adopter and continuous and exclusive user 
of the said trademark in respect of unmanufactured tobacco/tobacco since 
12th February, 1990. Therefore, the trademark registered in favour of the 
respondent no.1 is liable to be cancelled in terms of Section 57 of the Act. 
18. 
The impugned registration under no.4256368 in Class 34 remains on 
the Register of Trade Marks without sufficient cause.  
19. 
Accordingly, the present petition is allowed and the trademark 
registered under application no.4256368 in the name of the respondent no.1
